Award.AwardTitle: Novel Research - Teaching Integration Strategies for Undergraduate Student Participation and Success in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project launches a novel research-teaching integration program where undergraduate fellow-faculty mentor teams conduct basic research at a level suitable for publication in peer-reviewed journals and use the results to develop new lectures and/or laboratory modules. The modules are then presented by the undergraduate fellows in undergraduate courses taught at the University of Texas at El Paso and at the El Paso Community College (EPCC), as appropriate. Students enrolled in the courses evaluate how effectively their undergraduate peers design and deliver the modules, while their learning outcomes are evaluated by traditional means such as tests and/or lab reports. Evaluation results are analyzed and used to improve the program. Integrating mentored research, guided curriculum design, and peer-led teaching and learning is expected to have a synergistic effect, the impact of which extends beyond the training of sponsored students, scientific discoveries, and new teaching strategies. The project is expected to provide research data on how effectively STEM undergraduate learning, retention, graduation rates and career preparation are enhanced through training and skills improvement of undergraduate fellows. The new modules, along with research and evaluation results, are being disseminated locally and nationally at symposia and conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The STEM Research-Teaching Integration (STEM-RTI) program at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) was a two-year project that financially supported and engaged eight undergraduate STEM majors (RTI fellows) in a series of activities that combine three high-impact educational practices: mentored research, guided curriculum design and peer-led teaching and learning.  The goal of the project was to ensure the students completed their STEM degrees in time while preparing them early-on for academic research and teaching before entering graduate school or the STEM workforce. Students conducted research under the supervision of a faculty member of their choice, and, based on results and topic fit, developed new lectures and/or laboratory modules that use active learning techniques. The students then delivered the lessons to peers taking a course in which their research mentor was the instructor of record. The RTI fellows  had never taken education/pedagogy courses, to ensure they were prepared to develop their modules with appropriate active learning pedagogical techniques, they participated in two workshops on active learning facilitated by the director of the UTEP Center for Excellence in Teaching and Learning (CETaL). Their mentors were present in during the training. After preparing their modules, the students practiced them in front of and received feedback from their corresponding mentors, the program directors, the evaluator and the director of CETaL. The new modules, which had their basis onf the research the students were conducting, were presented by the STEM-RTI fellows in courses taught at UTEP. This process gave the fellows first-hand experience on the effort needed to prepare effective lessons and immersed them in the excitement of teaching.

The survey results show that the STEM-RTI program benefitted student participants in terms of both attitude and skills. All fellows reported that the experience confirmed their interest in their discipline, and prepared them for graduate school, a teaching career and a job. The experience solidified the decision of all participants to pursue advanced degrees and all but one participant to remain in STEM careers. Relevant to the intellectual merit criteria, the findings show that all the undergraduate fellows achieved gains in aspects that are related to successfully conduct research in the sciences, communicating their research results to others who are not experts, and understanding the effort needed to effectively teach undergraduate students.

All STEM-RTI fellows completed their degree in less time or the same amount of time as their population peers, and most of them expressed their intent to pursue teaching opportunities. Four of the seven participants (57%) are of Hispanic origin (broader impact).

The 203 students who attended the classes where the RTI fellow presented their modules indicated that the module presented by their peer stimulated their interest to conduct research. The majority of these undergraduate students (82%) are Hispanic (broader impact).

 Faculty participants reported on three useful elements of the program: students are a resource to develop curriculum to implement in courses and to lessen faculty lecture load; active learning creates a ripple effect by encouraging more students to participate in class; and identifying learning goals allows recognition that there are learning outcomes associated with research and teaching (broader impact).

The project also significantly influenced the teaching strategies of three of the faculty mentors who participated in the project. They agreed to develop research intensive courses that engage students in authentic research experiences directly related to their research agendas. One such course has already been piloted and two are under development (broader impact).
